There's a lot of different subjects anime can tackle. From the mundane lives of children and their parents to heroes following prophecies long forgotten in order to save the world. There is certainly no shortage of anime tackling the modern day every-family with all its trials and tribulations. But what would happen if you replaced the family in those anime with a facsimile of the Chinese imperial family and you added a heroic prophecy to the mix? Well you might get something similar to Moribito: Guardian of the Spirit. Part adventure anime, part parenting slice of life anime and part chinese fantasy Moribito manages tomix these elements into an interesting, if at times a little rushed, story that places more focus on its characters and world than on the actual story being told.


Moribito describes the journey of Balsa and Prince Chagum as they run away from the empire who would seek to harm the prince. The anime is split into three somewhat distinct parts which each have their strong points and weak points.

The first part is the introduction and the flight from imperial capture. Here we get to meet most of the important cast of the show and a great deal of time is spent laying the groundwork for the way the empire functions and the way the magic and world function. This part is more focused on action and movement than the others with our pair needing to be on the move to escape captors. Because of this it manages to create a lot of tension and very early on it also gives us what I think is the best action sequence in the entire show with the duel in the rice paddies.

Now while the first part describes most of the world quite well it moves at a break-neck pace, thrusting a lot of information into your face and expecting you to just take it in. Some things also just never get explained. For example, we are shown a few examples of the magics that one character, Torogai, can perform but we are never given more explanation than "she's a magicweaver". And that is true for basically all of the mysticism in the show. It lacks explanation. Now being that these are powers that the characters themselves cannot comprehend at times maybe it's better this way, and it certainly does preserve the air of mystery around the supernatural that the show wants to have, I just would've liked a little bit more than a handwave. Same goes for the imperial star reader faction, we never actually get to see any star reading we're just supposed to believe what the anime tells us.


The second part of the show slows down considerably and takes on an almost slice of life feeling. It is generally calm with not much action going on and even when there is the occasional problem it's generally nothing life-threatning. This arc is devoted to having Chagum and Balsa grow close, not unlike a mother and her child. This is where the parenting aspect of the anime comes into play. The two main characters get ample time to bond and to establish their feelings towards each other. Some may find this part rather dull compared to the previous one, I for one welcomed the reprieve. This part is truly where we get to experience more of the characters rather than the world or the story which is put on the backburner. While I do like this part, it feels kind of empty now looking back considering that some of the characters featured in here have no real impact on the bigger picture. And that brings up a problem I have with the show, it tries to introduce and keep as many characters relevant as it possibly can but it doesn't manage to do that. It only manages to keep a relatively small core cast and quietly gets rid of seemingly still important characters, like the emperor here called the mikado, after they have exhausted their usefulness to the story. Some of these keep getting passing mentions or small roles after their story is over, but it just leaves and empty feeling regardless. Near the beginning of the series we spend some time out of an episode getting to know one of Chagum's pursuers in particular, a man named Jin who even gets his own flashback sequence and everything. He gets built up to be some sort of antagonist that will hamper the group out of a false sense of loyalty but all the build-up ultimately leads to nothing. He becomes an extra, a footnote that we for some reason spent some time getting to know.


The third and final part of the show delves into the mysticism and magic of the world more than any of the other parts and also brings the overarching plot to a head. We see our characters trying to decipher and bring to a close a prophecy and we even get a heel-turn from the mikado who realises his earlier mistakes in trying to kill his child. The build-up towards the finale all points to a happy ending, with even former enemies becoming friends. This, whether the anime actually wants it or not, creates a very tense atmosphere where main cast feels like it could be backstabbed by the imperial army at any point. This is also where the aforementioned Jin could have actually done some sort of betrayal and the anime certainly hints at this, but it all gets defalted in one scene in the final few episodes. It feels very anti-climactic. The entire finale does. Up until the very end the story is very tense and suspensful but it somehow manages to deflate at the end leaving an empty feeling. Writing this now I feel like all I've said about the anime is that it keeps leaving an empty feeling, yet why do I like it so much?


I like it because of the atmosphere, worlds and characters it presents. It's an anime that barring its finale knows when to be calm, knows when to have action and knows when to have some drama. It creates a world full of hidden mysteries and magic that we sadly do not get to explore all that much. It has beautiful environments, from rocky mountains to lush forests and rich ricefields the anime is gorgeous to look at all throughout. The character designs also look great and complement the chinese inspired world. All in all Moribito is a beautiful anime and manages to do almost everything it sets out to do quite well. The animation looks great, especially the occasional fight or action sequence is a feast for the eyes. Not to mention the two main characters; Balsa giving an example of how to create a strong female character both physically and mentally while also keeping her from turning into a woman-shaped man. Balsa is a woman through and through and it the show reminds us by showing her at times motherly interactions with Chagum. Chagum, is a child character that is also quite well done. He behaves as you would expect a noble child to behave in the beginning but grows into his own person by the end of the anime and the journey is a joy to observe.

The overall atmosphere of the anime is superb and it is only aided by the wonderful soundtrack by Kenji Kawai.


In conclusion, would I recommend you watch Moribito: Guardian of the Spirit? Yes. Definitely yes. If you let it take you and pull you into its world you will get to experience one of anime's finest fantasies. While it does have some glaring faults, like not being able to reach a climax no matter what, it can all be overlooked when looking at all it does well. I'd say that everyone should at one point or another get to experience Moribito, but I would say that if you are a fan of medieval or historical fantasy worlds and want a break from all the Tolkien inspired worlds full of elves and evil lords then you should drop everything now and watch this immediately.

Seirei No Moribito is a peculiar anime that made me feel genuinely elated. For a long time as an anime fan, I have not seen any fantasy anime capture a raw sense of realism and tranquility as Seirei did. The opening theme is quite memorable and uplifting, putting you in the mood to watch the latest episode in its 26-episode run. The characters are extremely well-fleshed out as the interactions in everyday situations between Chagum, Tonda, and Balsa is always a treat to witness. The 3D animated background interspersed with the 2D drawn out characters makes for great contrast (i.e. it worked well in thiscase unlike a full-on trainwreck of a 3D-anime, Berserk 2016). The fight scenes were beautifully rendered with actually some variety in the sounds of weapons clashing if you're careful enough to notice. The story had a bit of a slow start in the first half, but got very compelling throughout the second half, which was pivotal to how well the show ended. The ending was very satisfying and well-executed, leaving us contented and hopeful for the coming of a second season as Balsa embarks on another journey. Sadly, no second season was announced, which is a shame as this setting, characters, and story all deserve high-quality animation as it got for one season. The spiritualism in this anime was a breath of fresh air from traditional fantasy anime as the characters interacting with and comprehending the unknown, coexisting "spirit world" was more the focus rather than having some random "spirit/other world" characters show up as a cheap plot device or fanservice (e.g. InuYasha). Moreover, watching the relationship between Chagum, Tonda, and Balsa evolve and grow in both mundane and intense situations was beautiful and stirring. I would recommend this anime to anyone who enjoys more mature fantasy anime that is more self-reflective of life overall than focused on fanservice.

Seirei no Moribito is a simple and straightforward story of Balsa protecting a young prince bestowed of the water spirit from a kingdom and father out to kill him in fear of the water spirit being born. On the other end, Seirei no Moribito was not holding back when it came to its action sequences either. These were some of the most intense battle choreography I have seen in a long time. The early chase/fight scene between Balsaand the King’s hunters come to mind immediately. Coupled with an excellent, I do mean excellent soundtrack, these scenes were keeping those eyeballs glued to the screen.


The animation on a weekly basis did not falter; on the contrary you were always asking yourself how the hell the show looked so good on a consistent level every week! I cannot forget the single lone reason that made Seirei no Moribito as good as it is. Balsa, the main heroin lead is such an amazing character. From bad-ass spear master to a motherly figure to a child (not her own) destined for doom she was the perfect character for this show. I find no fault with her. She wasn’t a typical stock-character, that and she looked god damn sexy all the time and had a very sexy voice actor, in a matured woman kind of way. The supporting characters were just as good. Chagum, carrier of the water spirit is a kid. If I hate anything in anime shows it’s when kids are the main characters. Most of the time they are whiny, follow no logic, and flat-out show killers. But you know what? Chagum grew on me. He had a lot of smarts in that noggin of his. He was smart, didn’t whine like a little bitch, and stood up for himself and showed those lowly scamming peasants their place in life in one episode. Tanda was cool also, but you just have to feel sorry for the guy, he never got any action with Balsa, which just makes you wish every time the show had even a small hint of romance.


A complaint to some, enjoyed by me personally, the slice of life / filler episodes did slow down the story considerably during most of the shows run. Coming to a close, Seirei no Moribito was a show I will not forget for some time. It had a gripping start, slowed downed in the middle for a bit, and finished absolutely perfectly. Very little flaws with the show on a whole, great characters, visually stunning animations, well choreographed fight sequences, suspenseful music, well written dialogue and well-developed characters, Seirei no Moribito simply had it all.

This series was recommended to me by an online friend with high praise and it sure delivered. I won't blindly say it was the best thing since my tastes do differ though it was much better then I expected.
Story - I give it an 8 based on my own taste. I place the genre half way between superstition and fantasy in a sense. The story explains everything provided you're paying attention like a fantasy without the doom and gloom of superstition. However it's also a lot of superstitious genre because the elements of fantasy begin to blend in to what feels like elements FROM asuperstitious source. The monsters don't feel like they are from a fantasy...they look more like they belong in a series where nothing is explained and we're all doomed! Some elements of the story also fit the superstitious genre. It's important for me to feel the need to say that the series HAS fantasy elements but is NOT a fantasy in and of itself. I define fantasy as unicorns, elves, fireballs, and wizards and I'd define scifi as ships blowing up other ships in space...so LOTR would at best be a very light fantasy and stuff like Crysis (the game) would be a futuristic fiction. So this is an old time time-frame of Japan with fantasy elements if you're one to debate the feel of such things.


The storytelling itself is well done and the few battle scenes are done nicely. The story has a fullness to it, I felt like the world as explained in the stories told had the believability element necessary for the story to have the effects you desire when watching a series, especially one that takes itself seriously. I do enjoy serious series but they have to be executed in a certain way and this one does it wonderfully.


Art - This is without a doubt one of the best animated series I've seen. I'm not in to gore though can tolerate blood however this series gracefully executed violence without the excess. I would have younger kids watch this before Bleach if you have a family who'd you like something to watch with. Many things from the first to the last episode impressed me and they didn't cheap out at all. Even in the last episode when you saw a hundred servants kneel at the same time I could see them animate it at least well enough so it looked realistic, it wasn't a solid line of a repeated animation that simple animated perfectly the same all at the same time. You'd actually see a few people slightly out of sequence which is one of the signs of really good animation (as this is what would happen in real life).


Sound - I didn't get to view this on DVD though I don't think the sound blew me away it wasn't bad either. I didn't really notice anything above and beyond though the quality was good enough for me.


Characters - The characters were mostly well balanced out though there are some small things that bothered me. Summary:
Seirei no moribito is an excellent action, fantasy/historical period type anime which is well worth the time and attention of anyone interested in this genre. It has great character development, beautiful animation, a gripping story and above all real emotion and heart. It is a more classic and dramatic style of anime, with no ecchi, overpowered characters or overt slapstick type comedy elements. I would certainly rank this anime in any top 10 list for historical action and I am sure any viewer would enjoy this series.
Introduction:
If you are looking for overpowered characters battling it out with magic and swords flashing, ecchi, simple romance andlots of comedy, then this is not the anime for you.


However if you are interested in an anime which is predominantly a relationship drama interspersed with some great action sequences set in a well realised historical world with elements of magic, then I would highly recommend this anime.


Story:

At it's core, this anime is about the relationship between Balsa (our heroine) and her young charge Chagum who happens to be the prince of the country. By some mystical  happenstance, Chagum has to go into hiding because he is thought to be the cause of potential drought and desolation since he is possessed by a water spirit. The story then revolves around Balsa's vow to protect and save an eighth soul and the revelation behind the water spirit possessing Chagum. 


Art and Sound:

I loved the character design. All the characters are drawn true to life with no moe elements or over dramatised colours, hair or disproportionately large eyes. The animation and colours are varied and fluid with some excellent fight scenes. I thought the OP and ED songs were great and truly fit the story well. The music was also suitably poignant and dramatic and I cannot fault the technical side of this anime, particularly given the age.


Characters:

The characters is what makes this anime great. All of them behave in a consistent and realistic manner, with their motivations clearly expressed and conveyed. The relationship between the leads and the supporting cast is also well played out with some genuine heartfelt moments. By the end, you will no doubt be rooting for our heroes and you'll feel their joy and their sacrifice. If anything, the only slight downside is the lack of significant romance, although there is a minor element. My personal feeling is that the best stories have to contain all parts of the human experience, parental love, romantic love, friendship, joy, loss, sadness, comedy and growth. This anime certainly covers nearly all these elements.


Enjoyment:

Needless to say if you have read this far, you can see that I truly enjoyed this anime. The story moves at a solid steady pace with no real dips in quality or boring filler. Above all, it finishes of well, a rarity in this day and age. The loose ends are essentially tied up and you will feel satisfied watching it to the end. What more can a viewer ask for?

Perhaps there is more to this possession.  The plot was not linear, there were layers and twists, though not that intricate, but they added great depth to the show.  I wasn't bored.
Animation -SO Pretty.  SSOOO PRETTY!  And the actions/movements were flawless.  In that cry scene I talked about, Balsa sprints across some ledge and throws something into the air, and you can see the details of the strain in her face, the bunching of her muscles.  Fabulous! \n\n

Moribito is fantastical. The story unfolds as if it is a lore or a fairy tale passed down for generations. It is full of magic and mystery, yet unlike any Western fairy tale. For instance, the supernatural of Moribito is supervened upon its natural world: i.e., whereas the supernatural hides from the ordinary in the West, the supernatural in Moribito's world occupies an invisible layer of reality. It appears that the world of Moribito is composed of many grids stacked up on each other –similar to Michel Foucault's view of knowledge. Interestingly, the nature of this world's knowledge and history accords to Foucault's view ofeach as well: history and knowledge are shaped by the powerful. 


Despite some of its gloomy undertones, Moribito is, at heart, a moving tale of courage and compassion. Each character musters up the courage to sacrifice their lives to protect the ones they love. This seems typical of Japanese anime, but I disagree. If one watches the show, one finds that their bravery comes from humanity rather than inhuman fearlessness or courage; it is full of weakness and doubt. This is evident from its focus on maternal love, nurture, loyalty, family, and friendship. Moribito is not simply a story about a hero fighting monsters to protect their friends and lovers. Much of the show's conflicts come from human beings. 


Another critical difference between Moribito and other supernatural shows is that the main character is a strong, female warrior. Balsa is stoic and courageous, yet kind and altruistic. She has an unwavering sense of duty and morality. Her stoic personality is complemented by the sensitive men around her – Tanda and Chagum. I believe that Chagum especially brings out the best of her, as she act as both his martial arts teacher, mother, and roel model.


Not every character in this show is flushed out and the animation can be quite strange sometimes due to its use of 3D animatino. Nevertheless, the actions scenes are exquisitely animated, and the way it sketches the world's landscapes and supernatural entities is a treat to the eyes. Hence, these minor flaws do not detract much from the overall quality of this show. I really wish there will be a second series that delves deeper into the mysteries of this world. Moribito did an excellent job at not giving too much information, thereby keeping the supernatural ever more mysterious. Although this leaves the audience begging for some answers, it doesn't ultimately disappoint us because the show gave the major characters' relationships a satisfying closure. In other words, a perfect starting point for a new season!

It's been a while since I've seen [u]Seirei no Moribito[/u], but I must say that it's one of the few shows that have stuck with me for a long time.
Again, it has been a while since I've seen this show, but I just noticed it on a different site for the first time and I thought it only seemed fair to give praise to such an amazing work.
The storyline, all though probably not entirely unique due to it's Asian heritage, is laid out for the viewer in such a manner as to feel quite unique. Although this series is pretty much your standard 25-ish episodeslong, I felt like I got WAY more out of this show than I would have gotten out of many shows twice its length. Pacing in the show was great from what I can remember. No major waits between important story developments, whilst still maintaining the ability to tell quality side-stories (almost all of which add something important back to the main storyline). And probably the best part of all (at least for me), is that all of the plot twists and side stories that are presented are at some point wrapped up and tied off nicely with a pretty bow, rather than being left in some discarded heap because the development team didn't have the time/funds/desire to finish them.


The music in this show might have been it's "weak point" in that it lacked any kind of super memorable OP or ED, but the music played during the show itself was always fitting, and never over-bearing. Subtly with background music is always important, and as with most everything else in this show, it was done amazingly well. I also might add that the sound quality of the show itself was amazing. The weapon sounds and such were quite authentic sounding, and this really added to the experience. The voice acting is also fantastic and very well cast.


What really made this show special though is without a doubt the characters. I found very few, if any, of the main characters to be two-dimensional, something almost unheard of these days. Chagum may have started out a little cliche, but his development over the course of the show made him a very interesting character. But the super star of the show and our main heroine is Balsa. Easily one of the best characters I've ever come across in an anime, Balsa is amazing. Instead of pulling the classic "pretty woman with overly large assets that's either perfect or totally useless"... they made her real. She's a woman with what one might consider "mild" traits in the anime world (I put that in quotes because I find her quite beautiful). She wasn't drawn to be some kind of moe-nightmare or knockout beauty, infact they don't even try to portray her as young. She's drawn to be exactly what she is-- a middle-age woman that has spent a large portion of her life as a spear-for-higher. And she acts like it too. Balsa is a tough-mother, and is absolutely the best at what she does. But what makes her real, and thus fantastic, is what the viewer slowly learns of her past. They also do not make her unrealistically invincible, which I think is vital to this story. Balsa will forever be one of my most loved characters.


Animation for this show was also amazing. A fantastic job was done by the artists to make all of the movement animation not only fluid in general, but especially during fights. They also took great care in accurately portray the different warrior styles. Many of the different warriors through out the show actually wielded and used their weapons correctly. Spear wielders actually fought like spear wielders, sword fighters fought like sword fighters, etc. It's obvious that this studio put a lot of time and effort into researching and getting the different stances and weapons correct. The background art and characters designs were also all beautifully done. And one last time I'll mention that they did a good job of making the characters in this show feel much more real by portraying them more accurately, rather than taking the standard anime route and making them feel extremely over the top.


All-in-all, this is one of my personal all-time favorite shows, and I absolutely recommend it to anyone and everyone. There are very few weaknesses in this show, and none of them detract from the show in any way. Except you might want to physically harm Chagum from time to time. No biggie. Haha.

In 2007, I had just started getting serious about watching anime, particularly those that have just aired during that year, while following some others as well. One title happened to slip my grasp: Seirei no Moribito. I knew of it's existence, but I thought it was one of those political fantasies that seemed really hard to understand, like Guin Saga, which I haven't watched. After feeling rather bored one day, I decided to try out Moribito...and boy, am I glad I did! I can't believe I overlooked this show back in 2007! How could I be so insensitive?! But now I've finished it and I'mglad to say that this anime is on my top 30!


The story's about a young woman named Balsa who's traveling from her native town working as a bodyguard. She saves the life of the royal family's youngest son, the second prince Chagum, from falling into a river. The second queen, Chagum's mother, asks her to take care of her son and protect him because he has some kind of water demon in him, and because the water demon is said to bring torrid droughts every few hundred years, his father, the Mikado, wants him assassinated because he feels that Chagum's death will stop the drought. Balsa takes Chagum under her wing and protects him while finding a way to bring the water demon out of him. Assisting them on their journey are Tanda, Balsa's childhood friend and a herbatologist, the eccentric magic weaver Torogai, and two friendly street urchins named Toya and Saya. But despite their efforts, the Mikado's assassins want Chagum dead at all costs, and they'll stop at nothing to bring them down.


If there's one thing I LOVE about the show the most, it's the animation! BY GOD, the animation and art on this show is just absolutely impeccable and amazing, and I mean that in the highest respect possible! From the epic fights to the smallest details in the most irrelevant things (like scratches on Balsa's spear, grass leaves swaying in the wind, footprints, etc.), the animators surely brought everything to life! But what impressed me the most about the animation is how the characters are animated. Nowhere in the show do you see super deformed faces or chibiness or anything like that. The characters move, act, and display both emotions and actions in a very normal and human way, which is VERY refreshing in most anime nowadays. And speaking of human, I'm surprised with how actually HUMAN these characters are! Nobody has special powers, nobody can move faster than the naked eye can follow, no super fast healing powers, NOTHING!! When I see characters that move too fast for the naked eye to follow, I just feel it's lazy animating and too shounen anime-esque. Thank God, Moribito avoided this flaw awesomely and with aplomb (you'll notice if you watch the fight scenes, which there are only about four or five in the entire show)! Well, I guess part of this is due to the fact that it's adapted from a popular novel series, and I don't think novels can describe super speed that good, and the animators surely made use of this! And guess which company produced this? Production I.G! The people behind Ghost In The Shell, Blood-C, Bunny Drop, and currently, Guilty Crown. Some people say Guilty Crown's animation is awesome, but for me, pretty animation is nothing unless you've made good use of it and have some meaning in the plot. GC doesn't have that, and I'm gonna be bold and say that in my personal opinion, Moribito has WAY better animation than GC by a long shot!


The music...isn't really all that memorable or groundbreaking. Now don't get me wrong, I'm not saying I hate it or anything. On the contrary, I like it. It's nice and subtle, and knows when it wants to be calm and nice and go all out, and does so at the right times. But it's not one of my favorites. I did, however, love the opening theme! I'm not really a fan of L'Arc en Ciel (again, not saying I hate them), but I personally think this is their best song so far, and the animation certainly did it justice!


The characters...let me tell you this: in this show, there are absolutely NO flat or bland characters here. None. Zilch. Zippo. Nada. Nothing! Every single character, even the relatively minor ones, are complex and well rounded and far away from any stereotype we know. Balsa's the best and strongest female anime character I've seen, Chagum is the best damsel in distress I've seen, the supporting characters know that they're supporting characters, and best of all, they're all perfectly realistic and human characters without anything special to them. They all think like normal human beings and are quite intelligent. Don't expect any random stupidity or silliness or goofiness or anything like that. Nobody's mind-numbingly retarded in this series! Yay! I won't go into too much detail about why. You'll have to watch and see for yourself.


If I had to point out a flaw, it's that I think there should've been more conflict in the middle parts of the show and that I wish some of the supporting characters had more screen time. But in all honesty, that's about it. What I love is how misleading the show is. It looks like your political thriller, but it's actually a heartwarming tale about a mother's love for a child. I'd love to go into detail about this, but the love a mother has for a child is just too indescribable, so I'll leave it at that. I also love how the show develops its setting, by giving it traditions and rituals and some very well done back story. Heck, one of the episodes that had me on the edge of my seat, and got me excited the most, is one about gambling of all things! Gambling! But I think it was because I love the way they presented it. Also, I watched this whole thing in English on Hulu, and from what I hear, it aired on Adult Swim at some point. Man! If I had known about it, I would've DVRed it and watched it as it aired! Oh well, I watched it and I'm glad to say I love it! Also, the final two episodes are great as well.

This anime could have extreme potential: a physical world (sagu) that surrounds itself with the spirit world (Nayug), a female bodyguard with a dark past and a prince who's "possess by a water demon", follow by the whole state is after their necks! But, this adventure in terms of action was a let-down. Don't get me wrong I do enjoy the characters interaction and development like how Balsa shows her maternity instincts despite her rough treatment of Chagum, and Madame Torogai's harsh treatment was just for show. Itsjust I was expecting more great fighting sequence. The hunters look like an awesome worthy opponent of Balsa and I admit the fighting in the second to third episode was thrilling but thats all we're getting. Well, in spite of the let down, I still say this was a commendable anime.


This is because as aforementioned, the character development. Yet, there leaves more room for improvement like communication. Most of the communication is through body language, (so mad props to the animators cause the facial expressions and the scenes are just breathtaking) I want the characters to express more of their feelings. Its just that at times, they can appear a bit cold. But in the end you get used to it as you do grow an attachment to them and even can recognized the characters feelings through the actions and facial expressions.


As for the soundtrack, it was so-so. The opening and closing are the same for all the 26 episodes but they were great. I rather have a song repeated than get it replace by something far worse. But the background songs aren't memorable though.


For this anime it could have been so much more. I wanted more in depth background on Balsa or the hunters or even on Shuga. But you could only do so much on 26 episodes. Despite its drawbacks I still had a great time watching this. If your looking forward to anime that has that historical fantasy feel or don't mind the somewhat slow-pace, then this is for you. I rated this around a 7.9 since it does have its charms and there's nothing like this. So give it a try.

Serei no Moribito is simply beautiful. It is hands down, one of the best anime I have ever seen.
Set in a region similar to medieval Japan, it has one of the best examples of world-building ever. It is low fantasy by genre and eminently believable. While it has "magic" it is more in terms of folk witchcraft and misunderstood natural phenomena rather than wizards and bolts of lightning or anything like that.
The story itself is superb. It would easily translate into an excellent fantasy book series. I'd describe it best as an "adult fairytale". Something that could also easily be told with the words "Onceupon a time..." at the beginning.But it is also so much more than that.\n\n
The emotional impact is at times powerfully uplifting and at times heartbreaking, but what really makes it shine however is the fact that the characters are wonderfully complex. There are no cardboard cutouts. Even the "bad guys" are not evil, they are only doing what they believe is right. \n
Don't make the mistake of thinking this is one of those artsy anime however where all they do is talk and nothing really happens. It's an action-packed adventure. \n\n
Lastly, the art. From start to finish, the art is gorgeous. No lazy fillers or repeat tiles. Everything is beautifully animated and painstakingly detailed. Almost straight out of a painting. Its like that for Every. Single. Tile.

One of these days I will have to re-watch this anime series. Fulfills everything I want in a great anime masterpiece. You can't get better than Seirei no Moribito for artwork in my opinion. The background looks like paintings. The story is a interesting but the story is much about the ending as it is about the journey. The character development is really superb. The experience is a wonderful one. One of my favorite anime masterpieces that is actually very underrated. 
This anime works for all ages and it is truly very mature meaning that it escapes the frilly casual anime and it is inevery sense a masterpiece. In a sense, I believe that a person with much worldly experience and it is wise will tell you this is how they see the world...coincidentally how I want to see the world. That is how I felt about this anime. This anime is about courage, learning to love, friendship, caring about others, living through hardship... everything life is about to me. I highly recommend this to anyone. I believe anyone can watch this anime and get something useful out of it.

What is it: A low-fantasy slice of life series set in the Far East.
How good is it? I gave it a 8/10 (very good) when I reviewed it. It meanders around the middle, the plot does not feel urgent, and a couple brief CGI scenes look bad, but everything else is superb.
What is it rated: G, with no language and no fanservice.
Where to watch: All 26 episodes are on Netflix instant watch.
Notes: Don't judge a book by it's cover; despite the premise, there is actually very little action in this series. Instead, the plot follows the lives of the characters as they try to stayout of the hands of the Shogun and try to find out what is going on. Notable in that there are no actual antagonists in the series; everyone just wants to live happily ever after but a lack of information means they go about achieving that goals in different ways.

Moribito tells the story of the journey Bulsa and Chagum take as Chagum fulfills his duty as the Guardian of the Spirit and the prince of the Shin Yogo Empire. 
Story 9/10
In the opening credits of each episode it says how the anime was based off of a book and the anime really shows it. Usually in anime you can get a general idea of who this character is pretty quickly, but in this anime I feel like the characters develop a bit more naturally, much like they would in a book. 
A lot of episodes just focus on Chagum and Bulsa getting closer andadjusting to their new life together. For example, there's one episode where a friend of Bulsas, Touya, takes Chagum to the market, but Chagum has no concept of what money is because he's never had to buy anything before. As Chagum adapts to his new life, he learns more about life in the village and makes friends with other kids in the village. 


However, there is still some good action and fight scenes; I love watching Bulsa fight because she maintains this steely focus while fighting and never lets her guard down for a moment. Furthermore, Bulsa never kills anyone which makes it even more impressive she can beat her opponents without killing them. 


Besides Bulsa and Chagum, occasionally the focus would change to Shuga whose a star reader (basically this worlds version of a priest) at the palace and who continually looks for Chagum and Bulsa while also questioning whether the emperor's decision to kill Chagum is right.


Characters 9/10

Chagum: Chagum is my favorite character in the anime because I love how much growth he goes through and, again, it seems so natural too. For example, when Bulsa first meets Chagum he's this bratty rich kid that gets mad when Bulsa looks his mother in the eye, but then after Chagum leaves with Bulsa he become so quiet and timid which makes sense since he's in a new place with a strange woman he's never met. 


By time the story reaches the climax, Chagum has grown to care deeply for Bulsa and now understands his responsibility as the Guardian of the Spirit. 


Bulsa: A lot of people I know call Bulsa their favorite female anime character and, after watching the anime myself, I love Bulsa too. I love how tough and strong Bulsa is while, also, there are times when Bulsa lets down her guard and shows some emotion. If Chagums in trouble, Bulsa rescues him, but then starts crying because the thought of something bad happening to him terrifies her and she gets angry at him for not listening to her. This also shows how much Bulsa cares for Chagum and there connection. 


Furthermore, when you learn Bulsa's origins and why she became a body guard you understand why she keeps her emotions hidden and why she tries not to get attached to people. 


Shuga: Shuga may be more of a minor character, but I still really enjoyed him. I like how inquisitive and smart Shuga is and how he asks questions no one else thinks of, which in the end is an immense help to Bulsa and Chagum. Furthermore, I like how loyal Shuga is to Chagum and it shows how the thought of having to kill Chagum breaks his heart. 


Art 8/10

Something you always hear other people say about this anime is how plain Bulsa looks as in she doesn't have big boobs, big eyes, or colored in cheeks that make it look like she's always blushing like some other female anime characters have. I like Bulsas more simple and realistic design because it allows me to see her more as a real person and makes me take her more seriously. 


There some other more serious female characters in other anime like Hawkeye from Full Metal Alchemist or Tsunade from Naruto, but I think what sets Bulsa apart from them is how she doesn't have some goofy quirk or a chibi form. Bulsa both looks and acts very realistically and naturally. 


Another thing I want to point out is the design of the spirit world, Nayug, is really amazing and creative looking with all the giant animals and how it's so surreal looking in general. 


Overall 9/10

At its center, Moribito is about the relationship between Chagum and Bulsa and how they both grow as people from the journey they take together. It may be set in a fantasy world with magic and monsters, but it's very down to Earth with a story with plenty of twists and some fantastic characters.

This show features an adventure of a female spear-wielding bodyguard got hired to protect one of the Prince of the New Yogo Empire from being killed for possessing a demon within himself by escaping the Palace together. It also features how this spearwielder seeks to atone for the people who died for her to let her become who she is today.
The story was told rather consistent but there was one point where I felt a bit confused on whether it was a flashback. I had to rewatch a second or third time for those episodes to confirm so I guess it would be good tohave more obvious distinction from a flashback or the present time. The pacing, however was slow and steady which I rather liked, it had a good mix of filler episodes whereby we were shown to the memories of one of the character. I actually liked the ending due to the fact that it wasn't rushed at all and a satisfying conclusion. A proper farewell was done as well. Last but not least, I liked the fact that not all the information was given to the characters and this made the story a bit more interesting as they would rely on what happens and then they act upon it. This gives the show a bit of unknown on what happen next and the excitement which ensused.


The artwork was fair and simple to be honest, not the high resolution ones that you expect but the action scenes for the fights were rather intense. However, I would have loved it if there were more battle scenes but I guess this would mean more resources needed.


The sounds for the show was okay, the theme music did fit for various and different kind of moods and it did set the mood right.


The number of characters were all right, not too much and not too little. I extremely liked Balsa the spearwielder's story and background, especially her memories with Jiguro. It shaped Balsa for who she was in the show and how she relates it to her encounter with Chagum. Chagum, which can be said to be one of the main characters has also grown up rather well with all his experiences with Balsa and all his encounters with either the Egg, Hunters and etcetra. One specific character I would dislike is the present Emperor due to his self-contradictory words towards Chagum at the beginning and the end of the show. Last but not least, I also liked the honor-bound personalities this show had as well.


This show made me feel rather heartwarming for its story while it may seem a bit sad at times. I feel it's pretty well-written and could appreciate how it was protrayed from the beginning till the end. Lastly, I really enjoyed the ending as it was complete and not rushed like some shows.

While "Guardian of the Sacred Spirit", or Seirei no Moribito, is not your typical anime, it is one that is certainly easy to get swept up in. The historical solidity of the story is refreshing, and the elements of fantasy are very realistically executed from start to finish. The pacing even pulls the viewer in, making you thirst for more information every episode.
For the individual scores, the story isn't too much action, but successfully touches on all the important points, and holds tension between opposing forces very well without directly jumping into five to ten episode, knock-down, drag-out brawls. The art is more realistic, anddone in softer colors than the standard show of the day, the characters are flush and polot points are all covered in the show's entirety. Besides which, the show itself was just fun to watch! Always important.\n\n
If getting into something that lulls, at its' center, rather than being action all the through, is an issue, this may be a difficult show for you, but I encourage you to give it a try, regardless.

One of my favorite anime of all time. It's definitely one of the anime you just can't stop watching. I told my brother about it and he finished the series in one sitting (with a nap partway through).
The characters and story are great. There aren't a whole lot of characters but they really get into the backstory and flesh each of them out very well. The prince going from little brat to cool guy happens very naturally and believably. The overall story is great, the different factions, with their differing opinions on how to deal with the impending crisis, is very believable. It isn't justgood guys vs bad guys. It's people trying to do their best with the information they have. 


The art fits the series perfectly. No cartoony goofy stuff here. 


The music is perfect, traditional Japanese folk songs, drums for the intense parts, and orchestral stuff. I've watched the dub and sub, even the dub is good. In both the voices fit the characters well. 


The action is great. There aren't a whole lot of fights in this series, but the ones there are, are some of the best I've seen. They are very well animated, the music is intense and fits perfectly. The build up is there, and they are gritty. 


Overall it comes together so well. You'll laugh, you'll cry, the fights will have you totally pumped. A must see. 


I wish they would continue with the series, the original novels span 12 volumes, that could be 11 more seasons.

Fantastic anime. A splendid voyage of becoming encapsulated within the most beautiful animation I've seen for years. Wonderful musical score, superb scenery, well built and highly believable characters, all make this one of the best anime out there. There is so much to be said, but perhaps the most important thing is that although part of an anime, any and all of the characters are, above all, believable and relatable human beings. Each ruled by reason above passion and each worthy of respect and compassion. This, for me, is the single greatest achievement an anime can aspire to, and together with the elegance and masteryof the visuals, soundtrack, and story, it makes this, one of, if not the best anime ever made. Enjoy! I certainly have...
